questions.text: Mutation of which of the following aquaporin protein leads to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - Water and pH

Aquaporins Are Proteins That Form Water Channels in Certain Membranes.

In certain cells (eg, red cells and cells of the collecting ductules of the kidney), the movement of water by simple diffusion is augmented by movement through water channels.

These channels are composed of tetrameric transmembrane proteins named aquaporins. At least 10 distinct aquaporins (AP-1 to AP-10) have been identified.

Crystallographic and other studies have revealed how these channels permit passage of water but exclude passage of ions and protons.

In essence, the pores are too narrow to permit passage of ions.

Protons are excluded by the fact that the oxygen atom of water binds to two asparagine residues lining the channel, making the water unavailable to participate in an H+ relay, and thus preventing entry of protons.

Mutations in the gene encoding AP-2 have been shown to be the cause of one type of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, a condition in which there is an inability to concentrate urine

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number 489-490.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with progressive pigmentation on palmar area X-ray spine shows calcification intervertebral disk. Patient urine turns black on standing. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Amino acid Metabolism

Option B : Homogentisate Oxidase

The enzyme deficient is Homogentusate Oxidase. And the disease called as Alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria

  • Autosomal Recessive Disorder is due to a deficiency of Homogentisic Acid Oxidase
  • First inborn error detected.
  • Belongs to Garrod's Tetrad *Alkaptonuria, Albinism, Pentosuria, Cystinuria+

Biochemical defect

Homogentisate Oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate) which polymerises to form Alkaptone bodies.

Clinical presentation

  • Normal Life till 3rd or 4th decade.
  • Urine Darkens on standing is the only manifestation in children.
  • In adults Ochronosis: Alkaptone Bodies in Interver tebral Disk, cartilage of nose, pinna etc.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • Alkalanization increase darkening of urine.
  • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is reducing agent.
  • Ferric Chloride test positive
  • Silver Nitrate Test positive.
  • No Mental Retardation

Treatment

  • New Drug is Nitisinone [NTBC] which inhibit para Hydroxyl Phenyl Pyruvate hydroxylase which prevent the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • Symptomatic Treatment

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, page number 706

questions.text: Glutamate level is increased in blood, urine & CSF due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Urea Cycle Metabolism

Option A: Defects in carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I are responsible for the relatively rare (estimated frequency 1:62,000) metabolic disease termed "hyperammonemia type 1."

N-Acetylglutamate synthetase (NAGS), catalyzes the formation from acetyl-CoA and glutamate of the N acetylglutamate essential for carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I activity.

l-Glutamate + acetyl-CoA → N-acetyl-l-glutamate + CoASH

While the clinical and biochemical features of NAGS deficiency are indistinguishable from those arising from a defect in carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, a deficiency in NAGS may respond to administered N-acetylglutamate.

So glutamate level increased in blood in CPS I deficiency.

Option B: The X-chromosome-linked deficiency termed "hyperammonemia type 2" reflects a defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase.

The mothers also exhibit hyperammonemia and an aversion to high-protein foods.

Level of glutamine are elevated in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Option C: Argininosuccinate synthetase deficieny result in citrullinemia, plasma and cerebrospinal fluid citrulline levels are elevated, and 1 to 2 g of citrulline are excreted daily.

Option D: Hyperargininemia is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene for arginase.

Unlike other urea cycle disorders, the first symptoms of hyperargininemia typically do not appear until age 2 to 4 years. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid levels of arginine are elevated.

The urinary amino acid pattern, which resembles that of lysine-cystinuria, may reflect competition by arginine with lysine and cysteine for reabsorption in the renal tubule.

Argininosuccinate Lyase deficiency results in argininosuccinic aciduria, which accompanied by elevated levels of argininosuccinate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, is associated with friable, tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

Both early- and late-onset types are known.

Diagnosis by the measurement of erythrocyte argininosuccinate lyase activity can be performed on umbilical cord blood or amniotic fluid cells.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 28, page number:277

questions.text: Ammonia is very toxic to brain. In which of the following ammonia level in blood increase?
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Protein Metabolism

Increased ammonia in blood is suggestive of a urea cycle disorder. So answer is an enzyme (deficiency) of urea cycle.

There are different types of Urea Cycle disorders.

  • Hyperammonemia Type II (OTC Deficiency)
    • Most common Urea Cycle disorder
    • Disorder with X-linked partially dominant inheritance (All other Urea Cycle Disorders are Autosomal Recessive)
    • Levels of glutamine are elevated in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of enhanced glutamine synthesis in response to elevated levels of tissue ammonia.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, page number:683

questions.text: A 4 year old boy presented with photophobia. On ophthalmic examination, he has decreased visual acuity and nystagmus. He also has low pigmentation in skin and white hair. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein metabolism

Option A: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of Homogentisate into Maleylacetoacetate.

The urine darkens on exposure to air due to oxidation of excreted homogentisate.

Late in the disease, there is arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation (ochronosis) due to oxidation of homogentisate to benzoquinone acetate, which polymerizes and binds to connective tissue

Option B: Defect in tyrosinase leads to albinism, which leads to defective synthesis of melanin.

Skin has low pigmentation and is sensitive to UV rays, prone for melanomas and skin cancer, Hair is also white, Ocular fundus is hypopigmented, associated with photophobia, nystagmus & decreased visual acuity.

Option C: Genetic deficiency of Phenylalanine Hydroxylase enzyme leads to phenylketonuria, which characterized by mentally retarded with an low IQ, Agitation, hyperactivity, tremors and convulsions (because phenylalanine interferes with neurotransmitter synthesis), hypopigmentation (Inhibition of tyrosinase enzyme by Phenylalanine) and accumulation of phenyl ketones in blood and excreted in urine.

Phenyl lactic acid in sweat gives mousy body odour as well as also mousy odour to urine.

Option D: The probable metabolic defect in type I tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis) is at fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.

Therapy employs a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Untreated acute and chronic tyrosinosis leads to death from liver failure.

Alternate metabolites of tyrosine are also excreted in type II tyrosinemia (Richner-Hanhart syndrome), a defect in tyrosine aminotransferase, and in neonatal tyrosinemia, due to lowered activity of p-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase.

Therapy employs a diet low in protein.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter:29 Page number:286

questions.text: Free radical with highest activity:
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - Free radical & Anti oxidant

Points to Remember

  • Most powerful oxygen free radical is Hydroxyradical (OH⁻)Q
  • Least powerful Reactive Oxygen species is Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂).
  • Precursor of all reactive Oxygen species is Superoxide radical (O₂⁻)

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:564-567

questions.text: The 20-year-old girl finding difficulty in reading in dim light. She also has difficulty in vision during night while driving. Which of the following compound is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamins, minerals & nutrition

Option A: In the retina, retinaldehyde (retinal) functions as the prosthetic group of the light-sensitive opsin proteins, forming rhodopsin (in rods) and iodopsin (in cones).

Any one cone cell contains only one type of opsin and is sensitive to only one color.

The absorption of light by rhodopsin causes isomerization of the retinaldehyde from 11-cis to all-trans, and a conformational change in opsin.

This results in the release of retinaldehyde from the protein, and the initiation of a nerve impulse.

Dark Adaption Mechanism: Bright light depletes stores of rhodopsin in rods. So, when a person shifts suddenly from bright light to a dim light area, there is difficulty in seeing eg entering in cinema theater.

After a few minutes, rhodopsin is regenerated and vision is improved. This period is called as dark adaption time.

It is increased in vitamin A deficiency, due to less amount of rhodopsin.

The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark.

Night blindness: Visual acuity is diminished in dim light. The patient cannot read or drive a car in poor light. It occurs after gradually after impairment to adapt in dim light.

More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia (Bitot’s spot), keratinization of the cornea, and blindness.

Option B: Retinol is storage form of vitamin A in liver.

Option C: Retinoic acid act like steroid hormone, controlling the expression of certain genes, so regulate synthesis of protein involved in cell growth and differentiation.

Option D: Tocopherol is vitamin E, having antioxidant action.

Beta carotene is provitamin A, found in plant, has natural anti-oxidant property of carotenoids, prevent cancer & heart attack

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter 44, Page number:530

questions.text: A 45 years old male, known case of chronic kidney disease, have history of bone pain and repeated stress fracture. On examination, following abnormality is observed. A patient is likely to be suffering from deficiency of which of the following compound?
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamins, minerals & nutrition

This image showing Bowed legs due to osteomalacia, a nutritional vitamin D (calcitriol, active form of vitamin D) deficiency that results in demineralization of bone.

Option A; Ascorbic acid is vitamin C. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy, which is characterized by swollen and bleeding gums, haemorrhage etc

Option B: Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema; acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (Shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis; and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse.

The role of thiamin diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

In subjects on a relatively high carbohydrate diet, this results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, which may cause life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Option C: Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency can lead to pellagra. It is characterized by a photosensitive dermatitis.

As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Option D: Calcitriol is active form of vitamin D. Its deficiency results in demineralization of bone, leading to bowed leg.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrate Reviews Biochemistry 7th edition (South Asian edition) Chapter 32 Page number:542

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was found to have a hemoglobin of 7.8 g/dl. The peripheral blood smear showed a small and pale RBC as shown in image B (compared to normal shown in image A). Most sensitive indicator to diagnose Iron deficiency anemia is:
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamins, minerals & nutrition

Option A: Ferritin is storage form of iron, so reduced ferritin is diagnostic of iron deficiency anemia.

Maximum iron content of ferritin around 25% of its weight. Normal plasma contains very little ferritin (20 to 250 ng/ml).

Ferritin level in blood is an index of body iron stores. In iron deficiency anemia, ferritin is reduced. In iron overload, ferritin level is increased.

Also a positive acute phase protein, so level is elevated in inflammatory conditions

Option B: Serum Iron concentration is decreased in iron deficiency anemia (Normal - 60 to 160 microgm/dL).

But serum iron concentration is affected by many factor, so not a good indicator of iron deficiency.

Option C: Plasma transferrin can bind with 400 microgm of iron, which is known as Total Iron binding capacity (TIBC), so normal TIBC is in plasma, is around 450 microgm/dl (Normal range: 250 to 450 microgm/dl.)

In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased due to increase in transferrin concentration and reduced in serum iron concentration.

Option D: Transferrin (also known as Siderophilin) is a transport protein for iron. 1 molecule of transferrin can transport 2 ferric atoms.

It is synthesized in liver and half life is only 7–10 day. Normal plasma level is 215 to 365 mg/dl. In iron deficiency, this level is increased. Useful index of nutritional status also

Reference: Lippincott Illustrate Reviews Biochemistry 7th edition (South Asian edition) Chapter: 33 Page number:558

choices.text: Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA

questions.text: Biotin act as a coenzyme for many enzymes. Which of the following reaction does not require biotin:
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamin - Vitamin Metabolism

Biotin functions to transfer carbon dioxide in a small number of reactions: acetyl-CoA carboxylase, pyruvate carboxylase, propionyl-CoA carboxylase, and methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase.

A holocarboxylase synthetase catalyzes the transfer of biotin onto a lysine residue of the apo-enzyme to form the biocytin residue of the holoenzyme.

The reactive intermediate is 1-N-carboxybiocytin, formed from bicarbonate in an ATPdependent reaction.

The carboxyl group is then transferred to the substrate for carboxylation.

Biotin also has a role in regulation of the cell cycle, acting to biotinylate key nuclear proteins.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:561

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented to physician with tingling, numbness and weakness of muscle. His family gives history of narcotic abuse. A diagnosis of chronic peripheral neuritis was made. Which vitamin is deficient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamin - Vitamin Metabolism

Above patient having beriberi associated with chronic peripheral neuritis (dry beriberi) which occurs due to Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) deficiency. It is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse.

Option A: Although Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is centrally involved in lipid and carbohydrate metabolism, and deficiency occurs in many countries, it is not fatal, because there is very efficient conservation of tissue riboflavin.

Riboflavin released by the catabolism of enzymes is rapidly incorporated into newly synthesized enzymes.

Deficiency is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation and inflammation of the tongue, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option B: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy.

Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen.

Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss, and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis (leading to delayed wound healing), and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option C: Vitamin B1 (Thiamin) deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema; acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (Shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis; and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse.

The role of thiamin diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

In subjects on a relatively high carbohydrate diet, this results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, which may cause life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Option D: Although clinical deficiency disease is rare, there is evidence that a significant proportion of the population has marginal vitamin B6 status.

Moderate deficiency results in abnormalities of tryptophan and methionine metabolism.

Increased sensitivity to steroid hormone action may be important in the development of hormone-dependent cancer of the breast, uterus, and prostate, and vitamin B6 status may affect the prognosis.

The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro, expressed as the activation coefficient.

Measurement of plasma concentrations of the vitamin is also used.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition Chapter:44 Page number :534

questions.text: A 30 year old business executive male has pin point haemorrhage in skin along with following oral manifestation. He is taking processed and stored food due to his continuous business trip since last few days. Which of the following reaction is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamin - Vitamin Metabolism

Option A: This oral manifestation showing swollen bleeding gums (scurvy) which occurs due to vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency.

Such gums occur due to defect in synthesis of collagen.

Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required hydroxylation of proline and lysine which is required for the post synthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both these enzymes require vitamin C.

Option B: Carboxylation process required vitamin K, which is important for blood clotting.

Option C: phosphorylation dephosphorylation is a mechanism of covalent modification of enzyme, help in enzyme regulation.

Option D: Mineralization process is required for formation of bone and teeth, involve vitamin D.

Reference: Lippincott Illustrate Reviews Biochemistry 7th edition (South Asian edition) Chapter:32 Page number:528

questions.text: A 52 year old female, known case of pyloric stenosis, presented in emergency with complaints of persistent vomiting for one week and had generalized muscular cramps. On examination he appeared dehydrated and had shallow respiration. Arterial blood sample was analysed and shows pH: 7.63, HCO3-: 38 mmol/L, pCO2: 55 mmHg. What is the acid-base disturbance present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topic: Miscellaneous - Acid base balance

Normal pH is 7.35 to 7.45 (7.40), pCO2 is 35 to 45 mm Hg (40 mm Hg) & Bicarbonate level is 22 to 26 mmol/L (24 mmol/L).

Option B: In Metabolic alkalosis, pH is high, pCO2 is high & bicarbonate is high.

The pattern of high pH, with high HCO3 and raised pCO2 is highly suggestive of metabolic (non respiratory) alkalosis (raised pCO2 is due to compensatory hypoventilation).

The patient lost acidic gastric contents with vomitus.

To make up the loss, the carbonate dehydratase mechanism is stimulated in gastric parietal cells, which generate H+ as well as HCO3- in equimolar ratio.

While the H+ is secreted in gastric lumen and lost from there in vomiting, HCO3- are retained.

This results in primary HCO3- excess, leading to metabolic alkalosis. Also in pyloric stenosis, the loss of alkaline duodenal contents with vomitus is minimal, resulting in aggravation of alkalosis.

Option A: In Metabolic acidosis, pH is low, pCO2 is low & bicarbonate is low.

Option C: In Respiratory acidosis, pH is low, pCO2 is high & bicarbonate is high.

Option D: In Respiratory alkalosis, pH is high, pCO2 is low & bicarbonate is low.


Reference: Harrison's principle of internal medicine 21st edition Chapter:55 Page number:359

choices.text: Two Fab fragments and two Fc fragments
Two Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
Three Fab fragments and two Fc fragments
Three Fab fragments and three Fc fragments

questions.text: Papain is a proteolytic enzyme extracted from plant of papaya (carica papaya). It catalyzes protein breakdown by hydrolysis. It a single Immunoglobulin G (IgG) molecule is treated with this enzyme, then IgG will breakdown into following fragments?
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - Immunochemistry

Proteolytic cleavage of Immunoglobulin:

Immunoglobulin can be split by enzyme papain & Pepsin.

  • Papain cleaves at N-terminal side of inter heavy chain disulphide bonds, so produces two identical Fab and one Fc part.
  • Pepsin cleaves at C-terminal side of inter heavy chain disulphide bonds, so produces a large F(ab)2 fragment (composed of two attached Fab fragments) and Fc fragment is extensively degraded.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Page number: 641

questions.text: A 52-year aged person came with complaint of palmar pigmentation. Clinician order X-ray of lumber spine. X-ray spine shows calcification intervertebral disk. Patient urine turns black on standing. Which of the following disease is this person suffering from?
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Amino acid Metabolism

The disease called as Alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria

  • Autosomal Recessive Disorder is due to a deficiency of Homogentisic Acid Oxidase
  • First inborn error detected.
  • Belongs to Garrod's Tetrad *Alkaptonuria, Albinism, Pentosuria, Cystinuria+

Biochemical defect

Homogentisate Oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of Homogentisic Acid (Homogentisate) which polymerises to form Alkaptone bodies.

Clinical presentation

  • Normal Life till 3rd or 4th decade.
  • Urine Darkens on standing is the only manifestation in children.
  • In adults Ochronosis: Alkaptone Bodies in Interver- tebral Disk, cartilage of nose, pinna etc.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • Alkalanization increase darkening of urine.
  • Benedicts test positive in urine because homogentisic acid is reducing agent.
  • Ferric Chloride test positive
  • Silver Nitrate Test positive.
  • No Mental Retardation

Treatment

  • New Drug is Nitisinone [NTBC] which inhibit para Hydroxyl Phenyl Pyruvate hydroxylase which prevent the accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • Symptomatic Treatment

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, page number:706

questions.text: Which one of the following enzyme is used to breakdown beta carotene, during digestion and absorption of provitamin A, taken from vegetable sources?
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamin - Vitamin Metabolism

The α-, β-, and γ-carotenes and cryptoxanthin are quantitatively the most important provitamin A carotenoids.

β-Carotene and other provitamin A carotenoids are cleaved in the intestinal mucosa by carotene dioxygenase, yielding retinaldehyde, which is reduced to retinol, esterified and secreted in chylomicrons together with esters formed from dietary retinol.

The intestinal activity of carotene dioxygenase is low, so that a relatively large proportion of ingested β-carotene may appear in the circulation unchanged.

There are two isoenzymes of carotene dioxygenase.

One catalyzes cleavage of the central bond of β-carotene; the other catalyzes asymmetric cleavage leading to the formation of 8'-, 10'-, and 12'-apo-carotenals, which are oxidized to retinoic acid, but cannot be used as sources of retinol or retinaldehyde.

β-Carotene and other provitamin A carotenoids are cleaved in the intestinal mucosa by carotene dioxygenase.

Carotene Oxidase, Carotene reductase and Carotene dehydrogenase are not used to break down beta carotene.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, page number:557

questions.text: Thiamine is intimately related to metabolism of:
questions.solution:
Topic: Vitamin - Vitamin Metabolism

Thiamine has a central role in energy-yielding metabolism, and especially the metabolism of carbohydrates.

Thiamin is intimately connected with the energy releasing reactions in carbohydrate metabolism

Thiamine diphosphate is the coenzyme for three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions:

Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Convert Pyruvate → acetyl Co A

α ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: In TCA cycle, Convert α ketoglutarate → Succinyl CoA (TCA cycle)

Branched chain α keto acid dehydrogenase (decarboxylase): Convert branched chain amino acids (Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine) → its respective keto acids

In these three reactions, thiamin diphosphate provides a reactive carbon on the thiazole moiety that forms a carbanion, which then adds to the carbonyl group, for example, pyruvate. The addition compound is then decarboxylated, eliminating CO2.

Also it is a coenzyme for Transketolase enzymes, Involved in HMP shunt pathway, two transketolase reactions

  1. Xylulose 5 P + Ribose 5 P → Sedohaptulose P + Glyceraldehyde 3 P
  2. Xylulose 5 P + Erthrose 4 P → Fructose 6 P + Glyceraldehyde 3 P

Also Thiamine triphosphate has a role in nerve conduction; it phosphorylates, and so activates, a chloride channel in the nerve membrane

Apart from these, there will not be any role of thiamine in fat, protein or mineral metabolism.

So Option C is correct, rest Option A, B and D is incorrect

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, page number:555

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme use for interconversion of Glycine and Serine?
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Amino acid Metabolism

Biosynthesis of Glycine

  • Glycine Amino Transferase catalyse the synthesis of Glycine from Glyoxylate, Glutamate and Alanine
  • From Serine by Serine Hydroxy Methyl Transferase. This is a reversible reaction

Glycine aminotransferases can catalyze the synthesis of glycine from glyoxylate and glutamate or alanine.

Unlike most aminotransferase reactions, these strongly favor glycine synthesis.

Additional important mammalian routes for glycine formation are from choline and from serine

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:283, 284

choices.text: Protein consisting of one polypeptide can have quaternary structure
The formation of disulfide bond in a protein requires that the two participating cysteine residues be adjacent to each other in the primary sequence of the protein
The stability of quaternary structure in protein is mainly the result of covalent bonds among the subunits
The information required for the correct folding of a protein is contained in the specific sequence of amino acid along the polypeptide chain

questions.text: Which one of the following about protein structure is correct:
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Structure of protein

  • Proteins with more than one polypeptide chain can only have quaternary structure.
  • The cysteine residues need not be adjacent for the formation of disulfide bond
  • The stability of quaternary structure is by noncovalent bonds.
  • Denaturation can be reversible also.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:39, 40, 43, 44

questions.text: Km changes and Vmax remains the same. What is the type of Enzyme inhibition?
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - Bioenergetics

  • Competitive inhibition - Km increases and Vmax remains the same
  • Noncompetitive inhibition - Km remains the same and Vmax decreases
  • Uncompetitive inhibition - Both Km and Vmax decrease

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:80

choices.text: Increased FFA mobilisation and decreased Chylomicron and VLDL utilization
Increased FFA mobilisation and increased Chylomicron and VLDL utilization
Decreased FFA mobilisation and decreased Chylomicron and VLDL utilization
Decreased FFA mobilisation and increased Chylomicron and VLDL utilisation

questions.text: In diabetes, the cause of hypertryacylglycerolemia is?
questions.solution:
Topic: Nutrition - Disorder

Abnormalities of lipoprotein metabolism can lead to hypo or hyperlipidemic conditions.

The most common of these pathologies is Diabetes Melkite's where there is insulin deficiency, this in turn causes excessive mobilization of FFA and under utilization of chylomicrons and VLDL.

This is primarily responsible to the atherosclerotic predisposition of diabetes patients due to the net effect of hyper cholesterolemia.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:582

questions.text: Endoplasmic reticulum - signal transduction is through:
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - Xenobiotics

The singal hypothesis proposed that the protein is inserted into the ER membrane at the same time as its mRNA is being translated on polyribosomes, so-called cotranslational insertion.

Principal Components involved in Endoplasmic Reticulum Translocation

N-terminal signal peptide

  • Polyribosomes
  • SRP, signal recognition particle
  • SR, signal recognition particle receptor
  • Sec 61, the transloconQ
  • Signal peptidase
  • Associated proteins (e.g, TRAM and TRAP)
  • TRAM is Translocating Chain Associated Membrane Protein. TRAM accelerates the translocation of certain proteins.
  • TRAP, Translocon - associated Protein Complex. The function of TRAP is not clear.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:555, 556

questions.text: In SDS-PAGE, proteins are separated on basis of:
questions.solution:
Topic: MISCELLANEOUS TOPIC - techniques

PAGE

  • Protein is separated based on molecular mass or mol wt/size and charge

SDS PAGE

  • SDS impart equal negative charge so that it masks the inherent charge of the Protein
  • Now Proteins separate based on Mol wt (Size) only SDS-PAGE in conjunction with 2 Mercaptoethanol or dithioreitol
  • Oxidatively cleave disulfide bond.

So separate the components of multimeric protein.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:28

choices.text: Help in the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate
Disulfide bond formation between two adjacent peptide

questions.text: Sulfur of cysteine are not used/utilized in the body for the following process/product:
questions.solution:
Topic: Mineral - Mineral Metabolism

Methionine is an essential amino acid, so it cannot be synthesized from Cysteine.

  • But Sulfur of cysteine is donated by sulfur of methionine.
  • This is called transsulfuration reaction.
  • PLP is the coenzyme of transsulfuration.
  • The reaction is catalyzed by Cystathionine beta Synthase and Cystathionase enzyme.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number:284, 285

questions.text: Glutathione:
questions.solution:
Topic: Amino acid & Protein : Protein Metabolism

Functions of glutathione

  • Free radical scavenging
  • Transport of Amino acid across cell membrane
  • Keep iron in the ferrous sate, so prevent methmoglobin formation.
  • Act as coenzyme for certain enzymes.

Reference: Harper illustrated biochemistry 30th edition, page number: 23
